Question: why does the upwards rushing air (while the chopper is falling) rotate the rotors? To do so (via the pinwheel or windmill effect), the rotors would have to be in negative collective pitch for the duration of the descent and then immediately be switched to full positive collective right before landing. However, if I come correct, full scale helis just go to 0 collective (NOT negative) and flare full collective right before touchdown...i.e. no negative collective. Meaning that autorotation only uses rotor momentum and DOESN'T actually use rushing air to windmill the rotors. Can anyone validate this?

Yes it works, but every helicopter has a death zone. It is the zone below a certain hight that does not allow you to perform the autorotate. In other words you don't have enough hight to fall far enough so that the blades can spin fast enough to perform it. Most wild life catchers, rescue teams, firefighters and farmers fly in this zone.

However, real choppers don't autorotate that well, unless they are really light.
For instance, you can try to land a Black Hawk in autorotation, but it's a heavy chopper, too heavy, chances are that you'll break your legs in the impact...
Sure, autorotation will prevent the Black Hawk from being destroyed, but it won't make it land as gently as this one...

Ok, Destin, I'm a helicopter pilot working on my CFI right now. I have really enjoyed your episodes about helicopters, but the part that really fascinates me about autorotations is the science behind it, and I think that this video could have been much more informative.

RC helicopters often have no rotor blade washout and are capable of doing negative pitch, while real helicopters don't do much negative pitch, if any. Actually, interestingly enough, the only thing that drives helicopter rotor blades during an autorotation is the "Driving Region", or middle portion, of the blades. See, the blades are sectioned off into driven, driving, and stalled regions, with the driving region in the middle section of the blade. The driven section, or the tip of the blade, creates a lot of drag. The inner portion of the blade is stalled, and is therefore a detriment. As you increase collective pitch, you diminish the driving region until it no longer exceeds the drag of the stalled and driven regions. There are good diagrams of this online.

If you were to look at a cross-section of the blade in an autorotation, you would notice that the blade can still create autorotative torque with positive pitch, which is as fascinating as it is counterintuitive. See, lift always acts perpendicular to the relative wind (angle of attack isn't related), and when you're in an autorotation, the relative wind is very much from the bottom of the blades. Because of this, the only thing that will stop the blade from being driven is if it is stalled, or if the airspeed is so great that the relative wind is too shallow to create a driving force. Well guess what? Towards the high-speed blade tips, the relative wind is at a shallow angle that places lift at or behind the rotor mast (negative torque, or drag). Towards the very slow root, you have a steep relative wind angle that exceeds the critical angle of attack and therefore stalls the blade. Towards the middle of the blade, you have a medium angle which provides that positive torque needed for the autorotation. Again, there are diagrams of this online.

I think if you included some more of the in-depth physics behind autorotative descent, you could really blow this out of the park!

No mention of the flywheel effect?  They use a downward pitch on the rotors to let the helicopter fall faster but force more air through the rotor to generate rotor speed.  The rotors store a lot of rotational kinetic energy from this mechanism and acts as a flywheel.

The speed during most of the time falling during autorotation is too fast to land safely but right before the helicopter hits the ground, the pilot changes the pitch of the rotors up which is the normal rotor orientation for level flight.  The energy stored in the rotor acting as a flywheel will keep the rotors going for a short period of time until the flywheel energy is used up.  That short period of time is enough to gently put the helicopter on the ground.

The trick is to time it right so that the helicopter doesn't level off too early or too late.  Too early and the rotor uses up all its flywheel energy but the helicopter is still too high off the ground.  If you're still 100 feet above the ground when you run out, you're going to have a very rough landing because you won't be able to build up rotor speed before you impact.  If you're too late to level off, you'll crash.

This is very similar to landing a conventional airplane without power.  The airplane pitches its nose and wings down to build up linear velocity to store kinetic energy whereas the helicopter stores rotational velocity for an emergency landing.  But the larger the rotor relative to the helicopter and the larger the wings relative to the plane, the higher the margin of safety.  Small rotors and small wings require a much steeper dive to build up enough speed to compensate for the wings and rotors with lower lifting efficiency.

On a side note, this is why helicopters are superior to multicopters.  The small rotors in a multicopter have two inherent problems.  First, they require more power to produce a given amount of lift due to their smaller rotors.  Second, multicopter rotors lack adjustable pitch.  But even if they had adjustable pitch, they would be extremely difficult to autorotate safely because you need to build up tremendous speeds before you have enough rotational energy stored in the rotors to produce a controlled descent.  The margin of error would be extremely tight.

You do know that Sikorsky didn't invented the rotary wing concept right? and that autorotation IS the main feature of an Autogyro, a machine invented by Juan de la Cierva after a friend of his died in a plane crash... 

In fact much of what Sikorsky did was based on de la Cierva's work..

Wait....they did not explain nor mention in this video that, during auto-rotation, the blade pitch should be negative at the start of the descent. Then change blade pitch back to positive to stop the fall. And the sequence of changes in pitch is not as simple as it sounds. You have to perfectly time it to prevent the blade from stalling (by giving positive pitch too early) during the fall.

To over simplify, what you do is get the blades spinning faster to actually achieve lift speeds by reducing the collective (shallower angle will allow for the air to press harder against the blades increasing the spin). Once you get close to the ground, you increase the collective (more of a lift angle) and because you have them spinning so fast already, you actually gain lift or rather drastically slow the descent. This slows the blades very fast though so thats why you do it near the ground.

It's important to note that during autorotation you're not simply free-falling while adding energy to the blades.  You quickly reach a steady-state rate of descent in which you're actually in a very controlled glide.  This descent rate will be similar to that achieved by using a parachute whose diameter is the same as the rotor diameter.  The flare at the end is just the icing on the cake.

in helicopters, "with power" is the term used to describe when the engine is turning the rotor. during an autorotation, "power" is removed from the rotor system by cutting the throttle to idle or if the engine fails. in some helicopters, the hydraulic system has a redundant feature called a pressure accumulator that in the case of engine failure, will provide limited use of the controls for an emergency landing.

Auto rotation is a complex process. To keep the blades turning is only a fraction of what is needed.  As the heli nears the ground, the pilot needs to trade the rotating momentum of the blade to lift and slow the heli down all the while keeping the right attitude. done too early and you crash, done too late and you crash too.

Full size choppers do not adjust to a drastic negative collective as the RC when auto rotating. It lowers the collective and then pitch forward.Similar to an Autogyro, the airflow from the forward motion helps the blade around. It is a balancing act as the mass is bigger that if you let it fall too fast as the RC does, it will not recover safely. Helicopter have a so called dead mans curve. It is a flight envelope wherein an engine failure would not allow recovery and transition to auto rotate.

Remember that rotating the helicopter around its length and width axes (roll and pitch) is done all by the main rotor using the same principle of acceleration that lifts it off the ground. Therefore, with the rotor spinning at enough speed, having stored enough rotational energy, maneuvers are theoretically possible (and evidently, as shown up there), although with quickly deteriorating energy. With no engine to produce torque their is no need for antitorque, in a perfect world at least.   Their is drag with the drivetrain components and with practice autos generally the engine is idled (electric RC's notwithstanding?) so there is still some torque being produced.  But the tail rotor driveshaft is connected to the main rotor gearbox so it is still being powered, just not by the engine anymore.
Got side tracked...  To end the autorotation after the flare, you level the helicopter generally right around but before it comes to a complete stop and pull in collective to cushion your touchdown.

...stop falling.  There is not enough energy in the rotor disk to simply pull collective to stop your descent so you have to use this method.  Consequently having forward airspeed at the bottom of the autorotation is a MUST or you will become a crater in the ground.  Which leads into height velocity diagrams or the "dead man's curve" which illustrate combinations of airspeed and altitude that a pilot can and cannot successfully autorotate with.

I don't know about how RC helicopters auto, but I've done them in real helicopters.  As soon as you lose power you push the collective all the way down to reduce their drag.  You "windmill" all the way down to your flare height.  To initiate the flare you pull the cyclic aft, but do not pull any collective (yet).  The inflow angle of air into the aft tilted rotor disk changes the angle of attack to something that can support the weight of the helicopter and you simultaneously slow down and...

This is a common reason why low altitude helicopters like police helicopters don't hover -- they constantly keep moving in a cyclic round path; they need that momentum to provide extra energy for the auto-rotation to work in the event of an engine failure; if they fall from low altitude 'stalled' they don't have enough energy to spin up the blades before impact.

This causes many people to think they are doing tricks when really they are actively pursuing a stationary target.

There's only one battery on RC heli's most of the time- the speed controller drops the voltage to supply the servos and receiver with some juice, the rest goes to the motor. When the heli is falling he changes the pitch of the blades so that the wind speeds up the rotor, building the blades' momentum. That momentum that was built up is released by turning the pitch back the opposite direction again so that it pushes air toward the ground, pushing the heli up - and all with no motor power - cool

Well beyond any issues with pilot skill two main things come to mind; mechanical failure, if the swash plate (or the mechanisms controlling it) fails then you can't execute the auto-rotation and second the ratios of lift to weight are different in a full sized copter. On a small model like that the large rotors provide much more lift compared to the weight so auto-rotation can slow the copter more drastically.

Not exactly.  You first must store up inertial energy in the rotors by dropping the collective (reducing the blade pitch) and descending rapidly, at this point, the rotors are being back-driven by your decent and are providing a good deal of drag, but not much lift.  Once close to the ground (this must be carefully timed), you flare and raise the collective (increasing the blade pitch).  This will trade the stored rotational energy for lift, but the blade will quickly spin down.

Correct.  The general rule of thumb is a 1000 ft.

All done with the pitch of the blades.  The rotor system's stored energy can be used by raising the collective at the last moment.  This allows for the rotor to be "spent" or used to provide a reasonably soft landing.  The landing must be timed, but is and can be done over and over again.  Pilots must do this maneuver hundreds of times in training.
Agreed.
1:51 DO A BARREL ROLL!!!

There are only a few that can, and extensive changes must be made to to rotor head before you're able to.  Titanium rotor heads, no lead/lag dampers, advanced rotor blades (usually made out of several different composite materials, Eurocopter makes a ton of these), twin-engine setup for redundancy, etc.
Not much honestly.
Perfect.

All he did was roll off the throttle of the blades, the servos for pitch change are still working because the battery is still on.  I imagine when they "cut power," they were simply sending the engine to an "idle" state.

Unless of course he's running with a dual battery setup.  Then the servos would continue to operate while the motor for blade power is off.

In a real helicopter, you have hydraulics that run on the rotational power of the rotor system.  Thus, the pitch can still be adjusted.

Negative.  Autorotation is a real thing.  Look it up.  The rotor system is similar to the back tire of a bicycle in that you can coast, whilst moving the pedals in the opposite direction.  An open-clutch if you will.  Allowing the blades to continue to spin while the aircraft is descending.  The pilot typically has less than a second (depending on the aircraft) to flatten out the blades (collective) before recovery is no longer attainable.
awesome video. and again - Im getting smarter thanks to you every day. ( =your video comes out)

Agreed, but autorotation is a known maneuver a helicopter can do.  Sure it takes skill, but it's more instinctual.  Drop the collective, pull back on the cyclic, maintain 65 knots during your decent, flare, pull collective, settle.

It's physics, not skill.

really the strongest reason this doesn't happen often (some helis, like the Lynx, can loop safely, for instance) - is because the living meat-bags inside the heli are very intolerant of negative G and sudden G-force changes - both these things are required to flip and hold the heli upside down. Of course there are structural limits too, but those can be circumvented. :)

One thing to mention with autorotation is that you need good height to get enough autorotation speed to generate enough lift & survive. The lower you are flying the higher your airspeed should be to compensate. If you fly low and slow you are a dead man :) You can also get into autorotation from very low heights if you're going really fast, but then you won't have enough reaction time before you hit the ground. "High hovers" can start autorotation from 0 knots.

Auto-Rotation is a very key safety feature in rotary wing aircraft, however some types of aircraft cannot perform this maneuver due to mechanical design limitations, Also, there is the "The Dead-mans Curve" essentially the aircraft is flying too low to build sufficient torque in the rotor blades to then alter the collective and rapidly decelerate the loss of altitude.
Police and Military Aircraft have to be very careful because of this as they often times fly very low and slow! Great videos sir!
